title: U.S. Banking Regulators Seek Comment on Third-Party Relationships Guidance
summary: The guidance highlights the risks banks face as they increasingly rely on third parties for products and services, observers said. The interagency guidance on third-party relationships proposed by three banking regulators highlights the risks financial institutions face as banks increasingly rely on outside vendors and financial-technology companies for products and services, industry observers said.

title: Ex-Soldiers, Security Officials and Businessmen Conspired to Kill Haitian President, Officials Say
summary: Assassination of President Jovenel Moïse has implicated more than 30 suspects in Haiti, Colombia and the U.S.. A range of people, including two former Colombian soldiers, met in recent months in the Dominican Republic and Haiti in a plot that led to the assassination of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse, Haitian and Colombian officials said Thursday.

title: Andrew Cuomo to Meet Investigators of Sexual-Harassment Claims
summary: The Democratic New York governor's interview signals that Attorney General Letitia James's probe is progressing. ALBANY, N.Y.-New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo will be questioned on Saturday by state investigators as part of a probe into accusations that the Democratic governor sexually harassed multiple women, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Biden Gives Germany's Angela Merkel a White House Farewell
summary: Longtime leader makes likely last visit as chancellor after years of strained ties with Trump administration; disagreements remain over Covid-19 travel ban, pipeline. WASHINGTON-President Biden welcomed Angela Merkel to the White House for what is likely her final visit as Germany's chancellor, with both sides highlighting improving trans-Atlantic relations despite diverging interests over energy and other matters.

title: Biden Says Situation in Hong Kong Deteriorating
summary: U.S. preparing business advisory after Beijing presses ahead with a crackdown that has seen arrests. WASHINGTON-President Biden said the situation in Hong Kong is "deteriorating" as the administration prepares to issue an advisory to businesses that he said would lay out what may happen as China furthers its crackdown on the territory.

title: Los Angeles Imposes New Mask Mandate
summary: Case rates and hospitalizations have been rising in the U.S.'s most populous county, which officials attribute in part to the Delta variant. Los Angeles County will again require the use of masks indoors, following a sharp rise in coronavirus infections since most Covid-19 restrictions were lifted in California a month earlier.

title: Congress Goes AWOL on Global Taxation
summary: The Yellen ploy at the OECD threatens a core constitutional power.. The Biden Administration is planning the biggest overhaul to American taxation in decades, and you'd think members of Congress might have something to say about it. But no, for the most part a strange silence has greeted Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's bid to rope the United States into a revamp of global tax rules that by design robs Congress of its sovereignty over tax matters.

title: Do You Need to Wear a Mask Again?
summary: The rise of the Covid-19 Delta variant is raising new questions about mask-wearing, even for vaccinated people. Here's what doctors say you need to know.. To mask or not to mask?

title: A Covid Vaccine Crossroads
summary: You can oppose government mandates but still favor mass vaccination.. Vaccines are the great success of the pandemic. Americans should be celebrating these breakthrough innovations that U.S. industry produced at breakneck speed. But instead even vaccines are becoming another front in the culture war.

title: Booksellers for Censoring Books
summary: A publishing trade group panics over Abigail Shrier.. The American Booksellers Association apologized Wednesday for a "terrible" and "serious, violent incident." What dastardly offense did it commit? The profound trauma occurred this month when the trade group dedicated to selling books sent out a paperback copy of a book some of its members don't like.

title: Intel in Talks to Buy GlobalFoundries for About $30 Billion
summary: Move comes as Intel is launching a major push to become a chip manufacturer for others. Intel Corp. is exploring a deal to buy GlobalFoundries Inc., according to people familiar with the matter, in a move that would turbocharge the semiconductor giant's plans to make more chips for other tech companies and rate as its largest acquisition ever.

title: New Heat Wave to Hit Montana, Idaho
summary: State leaders activate firefighting resources as blazes continue to burn across West. Another heat wave is set to hit parts of the drought-stricken western U.S. this weekend as firefighters battle dozens of blazes and state leaders activate more resources to support them.

title: Blinken Invites the U.N. to Investigate America
summary: The Secretary of State welcomes the Human Rights Council that includes Cuba, China and Russia to opine on systemic racism in the U.S.. Ronald Reagan liked to tell a story about an American who tells a Russian the U.S. is so free he can stand outside the White House and yell, "To hell with Ronald Reagan." The Russian says he has the same freedom. "I can stand in front of the Kremlin and yell, 'To hell with Ronald Reagan,' too."

title: Internet Powered Cuban Protests. The State Then Pulled the Plug.
summary: Communist-government shutdown of web and telephone services made it hard for Cubans to organize across the country. The wave of spontaneous protests that rocked Cuba on Sunday was propelled by social media and the proliferation of mobile internet, which Cubans have only had for the past three years. The government responded by leaving the island virtually incommunicado for two days.

title: 'In Their Own Words: Pope Francis' Review: Portrait of the Pontiff
summary: While there's no face-to-face interview with the former Jorge Mario Bergoglio in this PBS special, it's a flattering close-up of his life in the Catholic Church.. "In Their Own Words: Pope Francis,"

title: Biden Says He Expects to Give Update on Europe Travel Ban Soon
summary: The president says his Covid-19 team is evaluating the ban. President Biden said he expected to give an update on whether his administration would lift a ban on travel from Germany and other parts of Europe in the coming days, following an evaluation from his Covid-19 advisers.

title: Infrastructure Talks Stall Over Expanded IRS Powers
summary: Schumer plans initial vote Wednesday on roughly $1 trillion bipartisan package. WASHINGTON-Disagreements over expanding the Internal Revenue Service have snarled lawmakers' efforts to firm up their roughly $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure agreement before an initial vote next week gauging the deal's support.

title: Coming Face to Face With an Illusion
summary: Humans are hard-wired to spot facial features quickly so we can recognize friends or foes. That's why we see a face in the moon, or on a handbag.. Psychologist Susan Pinker explores new discoveries in the science of human nature. Read previous columns here.

title: The Reassuring Data on the Delta Variant
summary: There's no sign of a surge in hospitalization or severe illness, and the vaccines remain extremely effective.. You read the same alarming headlines every few months, now with Greek letters. As the virus that causes Covid-19 evolves and mutates, the same concerns pop up about whether the variant evades vaccines, makes people sicker than the old versions, and increases transmissibility. What we know about the Delta variant is reassuring.

title: 'Sleeper Agent' Review: From Moscow to Oak Ridge
summary: During World War II, an American-born spy stole secrets from U.S. atomic facilities that helped the Soviets build their ﬁrst A-bomb.. Many Americans are familiar with the names of the Soviet assets Alger Hiss, Klaus Fuchs, and Julius and Ethel Rosenberg. Few, however, have heard of George Koval, a devastatingly effective atomic spy during World War II who walked away from his exploits completely undetected by U.S. intelligence. Now writer Ann Hagedorn has told his story in "Sleeper Agent" (Simon & Schuster, 272 pages, $28), a historical page-turner of the highest order.

title: Canadian Graves of Indigenous Found Through Oral Histories
summary: Stories about children asked to dig graves and discovery of rib bone and tooth help investigators locate about 200 grave sites near a former school in Kamloops, British Columbia. KAMLOOPS, British Columbia-Oral histories of children being awakened in the middle of the night to help dig graves, along with a juvenile rib bone and a tooth that had previously been found near a former government-funded boarding school for indigenous children, were part of the evidence that led to the discovery of about 200 unmarked graves near Kamloops, in the western Canadian province of British Columbia, the researcher who led the work said.

title: Community College Is the Smart Choice
summary: It's a bargain at twice the price, and the stigma is misplaced.. I've had an almost comically varied career path, founding companies in education, robotics and beverages. The most surprising part of my résumé is the most mundane: I went to community college.

title: Oil-Demand Rebound Could Spur Inflation, Pressure Debt-Laden Nations, OPEC Says
summary: Cartel expects global oil demand to return to nearly 100 million barrels a day in 2022. A strong recovery in global oil demand next year could accelerate the pace of inflation and pressure countries with high debt levels, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said Thursday.

title: ServiceMax to Go Public in $1.4 Billion SPAC Deal
summary: Field-service software company to merge with Pathfinder Acquisition. ServiceMax has agreed to merge with a special-purpose acquisition company in a deal that will take the maker of software for field-service technicians public, the companies said Thursday.

title: Biden's PRO Enforcer
summary: What unions can't get from Congress, they seek from Labor nominee David Weil.. Some people fear the unknown. The Biden administration inspires alarm over the familiar. Consider the business community's welcome new focus on David Weil.

title: The Shul That Rose From the Ashes
summary: A suburb outside Moscow is home to a rich Jewish history-and a future too.. About 12 miles southeast of Moscow lies Malakhovka, a suburb surrounded by pine groves. This sleepy town holds some historic importance for Russian Jews, but what's happening there today also says a lot about a long-persecuted community's future.

title: Notable & Quotable: Booksellers and Banned Books
summary: 'An anti-trans book was included in our July mailing to members. This is a serious, violent incident.'. From the American Booksellers Association website, April 4:

title: How Is the Economy Doing? Here's What Banks Say
summary: Quarterly earnings from JPMorgan, Goldman and other big banks show an economy going strong. The question is, for how long?. Here's what the biggest U.S. banks are telling us about the state of the economy.

title: Republicans Hammer Biden on Inflation as He Heralds Economic Recovery
summary: Administration officials point to data showing that the labor market is recovering and consumer confidence is rising. WASHINGTON-President Biden is heralding an economic boom he says will boost Americans as the nation exits from the Covid-19 pandemic. But Republicans have pointed to the accompanying surge in inflation to hammer the president's party over higher prices for used cars, apparel and more.

title: 'Can You Bring It: Bill T. Jones and D-Man In the Waters' Review: Death-Defying Dance
summary: A documentary traces the evolution of a dance piece from its conception at the height of the AIDS epidemic to its recent restaging by students at Loyola Marymount University. Talk about leaps of faith. The huge one that's made by "Can You Bring It: Bill T. Jones and D-Man In the Waters" is that we will keep watching a feature documentary about dance, among many other things-not just watch it but see it and feel it-even though we may have little or no idea at the outset what the feverish movements signify. And watch, see and feel we do, with increasing absorption, all the leaps, lunges, plunges, spins, struts and death-defying belly slides of a now-classic work of postmodern dance that forms the centerpiece of a strong film with an urgent story to tell.

title: 'King Lear' Review: Live Among the Trees
summary: Christopher Lloyd is magnificent in the title role of Shakespeare & Company's 'King Lear'-the first theater our critic has seen in the company of others in 16 months. Lenox, Mass.

title: Head of Pentagon Innovation Unit Withdraws Nomination for Higher Post
summary: Michael Brown, seen as a leader in the Pentagon's drive to capitalize on private-sector innovation, cites an investigation into his unit. The director of a Pentagon unit that works with technology companies withdrew his nomination to become the Defense Department's undersecretary for acquisition due to an inspector general's investigation into his office.

title: Stocks Mostly Lower After Powell Comments on Inflation, Economy
summary: S&P 500 remains shy of record and Dow ends with its second-highest close ever. U.S. stocks ended mostly lower Thursday after the Federal Reserve's chief said recent inflation was uncomfortably above the levels that the central bank seeks and sounded somewhat less confident about the economic outlook than earlier in the year.

title: AMC, GameStop Swing as Meme Stocks Run Out of Air
summary: Shares of companies that have been popular on Reddit forums are coming back to earth this week, with Carver Bancorp and AMC losing over a fifth of their value. AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. and GameStop Corp. swung wildly on Thursday, extending a bout of volatility that has delivered deep cuts to small investors this week.

title: Here's What You Need to Know About Child Tax Credit Payments
summary: The payments can bring unexpected tax bills for some families. Today, the IRS made the first of six monthly payments in 2021 to more than 35 million families with nearly 60 million children. Some families received large payments. An eligible family with three young children could receive up to $900 a month for the rest of the year. The first round of payments comes to about $15 billion, according to a Biden administration official. Here's what you need to know about the payments.

title: CVS Pulls Two Sun-Care Products After Neutrogena Sunscreen Recall
summary: Drugstore chain says it will stop selling two CVS brand sun-care products out of caution. CVS Health Corp. said Thursday it has halted sales of two sun-care products in connection with a Johnson & Johnson recall of spray-sunscreens due to the detection of a potentially cancer-causing chemical in some samples of spray-sunscreens.

title: We're Back in Business (Friday Crossword, July 16)
Wall Street Moves to Close Markets for Juneteenth in 2022
summary: Trade association recommends that bond markets close for the full day on June 20 of next year. Stock and bond markets are moving toward shutting down in honor of Juneteenth next year.

title: Hooligan: From Figure of Fun to Menacing Fan
summary: Violent troublemakers got their name from a 19th-century Irish stereotype. England's soccer team lost the European Championship final against Italy last Sunday in a penalty shootout, and some fans reacted with violence, vandalism and racist abuse directed at three Black players who missed penalty kicks.

title: Tennis Skills Stalled? Four Gadgets to Make You the Next Djokovic
summary: Even tennis pros hit plateaus. Here, four pieces of gear they recommend to help so-so players overcome theirs, from a high-tech wrist strengthener to a camera that functions as an on-court referee.. AFTER COVID-19 changed the world in 2020, Alexandra Avila was one of the many Americans who sought the socially distanced salvation of their local tennis courts. During the pandemic, the publicist moved from Manhattan to sleepy Nyack in upstate New York, picking up a racket for the first time in a bid to hack her way out of the long grass of lockdown.

title: Gunman Found Criminally Responsible in Newsroom Shooting
summary: Maryland jury's finding means Jarrod Ramos will be sentenced to prison. ANNAPOLIS, Md.-A jury on Thursday found the gunman who killed five people at a Maryland newspaper criminally responsible, rejecting defense attorneys' mental illness arguments.

title: Morgan Stanley Still Has Room to Run
summary: Even with the rise in the Wall Street bank's shares and valuation, a big dividend and favorable trends could push it further still. Morgan Stanley is betting big on its future earnings prospects-and investors still can, too.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended July 10
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Fed's Powell Concedes Anxiety About Inflation but Resists Policy Shift
summary: Plans to reduce central bank asset purchases remain 'a ways off,' Fed chief says. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said recent inflation was uncomfortably above the levels the central bank seeks, concluding two days of testimony in which he sounded somewhat less confident about the economic outlook-and the Fed's policy path-than earlier this year.

title: Some Haiti Assassination Suspects Once Received U.S. Training
summary: The former Colombian soldiers are among the thousands of troops from that country to have received U.S. military training. Some of the former Colombian soldiers arrested for suspected involvement in the assassination of Haiti's president took part in a training program with the U.S. military, the Pentagon said on Thursday.

title: Pinot Grigios That Stand Out From the Rest: Our Top Five Bottles
summary: Some people love Pinot Grigio for its neutral profile. Not our wine columnist. She went looking for examples with real character.. IS IT A CRITICISM or a compliment to describe a wine as neutral? The term often appears in descriptions of Pinot Grigio, in magazines and books...and my own tasting notes.

title: The Secret to a Low-Maintenance Flower Garden? Beautiful Weeds
summary: Highway crews might mow them down all summer, but these native plants-so common in some regions they're not valued-deserve a spot in your plot. Here, all the tips you need.. GARDEN DESIGNER Butter Wakefield's London backyard, above, has nary a blade of grass out of place. Except, that is, for an untamed patch that contains what many people might deem weedy eyesores: tufted vetch, ragged robin and knapweed. Bracketed by a close-cropped carpet of grass and conically manicured yews in her tidy back garden, the wildflower strip gives the space an unexpected "wow factor," Ms. Wakefield said.

title: Netflix's Videogame Gambit Is Taking Shape
summary: The company has hired a Facebook executive to oversee a new unit dedicated to making games. Netflix Inc. co-founder Reed Hastings has often said he sees videogames as the streaming company's biggest competitor for customers.

title: 'We Are Not Afraid'
summary: From Havana to Hong Kong, brave souls defy communist tyranny.. After Sunday's unprecedented protests across Cuba challenging the island's dictatorship, the communist regime is still abusing its citizens. But in another rare occurrence, the regime is also beginning to acknowledge its role in creating their misery.

title: China Prepares Team to Investigate Deadly Pakistan Bus Blast
summary: At least nine Chinese workers were killed in the explosion, undermining trust between the two allies. ISLAMABAD, Pakistan-China will dispatch investigators to Pakistan, Beijing said Thursday, after an explosion this week claimed the largest loss of life of Chinese citizens in Pakistan in recent years.

title: The Best Plant-Based Milks-From Almond to Oat-Rigorously Tested
summary: Whether you're vegan, sustainability-minded or avoiding dairy for whatever reason, these alternatives to cow's milk made from nuts, grains, legumes and more scored the highest in our tests for versatility and all-out deliciousness. ONCE UPON A TIME, in the plant-based milk section of your local grocery store, soy reigned supreme. Then, just like that, it fell out of favor, and almond milk became all the rage. Now, with Oatly's recent IPO and nationwide presence at Starbucks across the land, the faux milk of the moment is undoubtedly oat.

title: How Long Is Too Long for a Coffee Date?
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions on making conversation, bringing remote workers back together, and why people spread misinformation online. Behavioral economist Dan Ariely uses psychological research to advise on everyday dilemmas. Read more columns here.

title: Bezos in Space: What the Blue Origin Flight Will Be Like
summary: Curious what the former Amazon.com CEO and others on the New Shepard rocket will see? Picture yourself on the flight too-literally. When Blue Origin LLC's New Shepard rocket launches former Amazon.com Inc. CEO Jeff Bezos into space Tuesday, one seat will be occupied by 18-year-old Oliver Daemen, the first paying customer to fly on board the rocket.

title: Digital Ad Vet Anthony Katsur Named CEO of IAB Tech Lab
summary: The industry group gets a new leader at a time of change for digital advertising. Digital advertising veteran Anthony Katsur has been named chief executive of the IAB Tech Lab, a global nonprofit that promotes common standards and technology for digital advertising, at a moment of flux for the digital advertising industry.

title: Teen to Replace Auction Winner on Blue Origin Space Flight
summary: Space company cites anonymous winner's scheduling conflict, opening up a seat for 18-year-old Oliver Daemen. Jeff Bezos' space company said that the person who paid roughly $30 million for a seat aboard its rocket next week won't be on the trip, and an 18-year-old would join the launch instead.

title: Delta Air Lines, Meet the Delta Variant
summary: The fast-spreading Covid-19 variant's name doesn't slow bookings; 'We just call it the variant,' Delta CEO says. Airlines are trying to put the Covid-19 pandemic behind them. For Delta Air Lines Inc., by virtue of its name, it may be a bit harder.

title: Self-Driving Startup Aurora to Go Public Through SPAC
summary: Special-purpose acquisition company backed by founders of LinkedIn, Zynga Inc.. Self-driving technology company Aurora plans to go public through a special-purpose acquisition company backed by founders from LinkedIn and Zynga Inc., in a transaction that values the startup at $11 billion.

title: 'Schmigadoon!' Review: Musical Comedy as You've Never Seen It
summary: Cecily Strong and Keegan-Michael Key seek true love in this show-tune-packed Apple TV sendup of 'Brigadoon' and an entire theatrical genre. A savvy send-up of classic Broadway, "Schmigadoon!" is probably the best time one can have with one's TV at the moment. But it also solves the "problem" of musicals themselves. "People don't just burst into song in real life," says Josh (Keegan-Michael Key). And? "You seem OK with magical hammers that come back when you call them," cracks his girlfriend, Melissa (Cecily Strong). Josh parries with a faltering defense of Marvel movies, but the point has been scored: People are spontaneously singing. And dancing. And if you just loosen up for a second, it might be delightful.

title: Biden's ATF Pick Faces Uncertainty in Senate
summary: Gun-rights groups lobby against nominee, while several Democratic lawmakers remain uncommitted. WASHINGTON-President Biden's pick to lead the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives faces a narrow path to confirmation, with uncertain support among Senate Democrats and intensive lobbying by groups opposed to the former ATF agent turned gun-control advocate.

title: Lawsuits Over Digital Accessibility for People With Disabilities Are Rising
summary: New reliance on e-commerce and other digital experiences during the pandemic has exposed problems with accessibility online, advocates say. The number of U.S. lawsuits alleging that websites, apps and digital videos were inaccessible to people with disabilities rose 64% in the first half of 2021 from a year earlier, a new report says.

title: The Climate-Change Agenda Goes Out With a Bang
summary: Ambitious plans conceal growing voter skepticism. Politicians will catch on sooner or later, and hard.. We're supposed to view this week as a banner occasion in the annals of climate change. The European Union unveiled a mammoth new plan to control carbon emissions, while Beijing rolled out an emissions-trading scheme and the U.K. released a plan to green up transportation.

title: Lebanon's Prime Minister-Designate Hariri Resigns
summary: Country's political crisis deepens as Hariri says he couldn't reach agreement with president. BEIRUT-Lebanon's prime minister-designate Saad Hariri on Thursday abandoned his nine-month effort to form a government, deepening a political crisis as the country struggles with a cratering economy and medical shortages amid a global pandemic.

title: Why the Lawyers Cartel Is Pushing for Woke Law Schools
summary: The ABA's proposed accrediting standards would impose uniformity and call it 'diversity.'. The American Bar Association is proposing new accrediting standards for law schools that would make them more race-conscious, more politically correct and less intellectually diverse. The proposal should fail on the merits. It's so bad it should also prompt reconsiderations of the ABA's role as accreditor of law schools and of the U.S. Supreme Court precedent on racial preferences in law-school admissions.

title: Child Tax Credit Payments Totaling $15 Billion Arrive for Millions of Americans
summary: IRS issues families payments of up to $300 per child under program aimed at combating poverty. WASHINGTON-Tens of millions of U.S. households can expect to see their bank balances grow Thursday, thanks to the first monthly payments of the expanded child tax credit.

title: Despite Demand, Factories Still Aren't Humming
summary: Constraints from chip shortages to a tight labor market are holding back a manufacturing boom. Factory production is having a hard time shifting into higher gear. This isn't because manufacturers don't want to turn their wheels any faster, but because for now they can't.

title: Electric Bike Sales Are Surging. But Are Kids' Versions a Good Idea?
summary: Advocates of pricy, battery-boosted models encourage parents to take any opportunity to get their kids outside. Detractors say children are too irresponsible to handle the risk. Here, we debate both sides.. For the recurring series, That's Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments-one in favor and other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.

title: Senate Confirms Nellie Liang to U.S. Treasury Post
summary: The former Federal Reserve economist will oversee U.S. fiscal policy. WASHINGTON-The Senate confirmed former Federal Reserve economist Nellie Liang as the Treasury Department's undersecretary for domestic finance, putting her at the forefront of efforts to manage the soaring federal debt.

title: More Than a Year After His Death, Pop Smoke Has the Top Hip-Hop Album of 2021
summary: 'Shoot for the Stars Aim for the Moon' is the biggest rap album of the year; a second posthumous album, 'Faith,' drops Friday. Here's why the late artist's legacy endures.. The biggest hip-hop album of the year so far isn't a 2021 release-it was already blaring out of car windows a year ago.

summary: Resume Subscription. When Patrick Coleman bought a home in 2017, he beat out eight other bidders and paid $100,000 over the asking price.

summary: Brooklynites Michelle and Dan Mannix are trying to sell their North Fork home as more listings in the area come online.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: What Proust Knew About Identity
summary: On his 150th anniversary, the great novelist reminds us that fiction can be truthful even when it's false to the author's reality. Few writers hold the world's attention long enough for their 150th birthday to qualify as an event. But then, it's hard to think of a novelist who has shaped readers' imaginations as profoundly as Marcel Proust, whose anniversary on July 10 inspired literary tributes around the globe. Ever since his magnum opus, the seven-volume "In Search of Lost Time," began to appear in 1913, it has been seen as a kind of master key to the modern mind.

title: Look for Health Stocks to Stop Lagging, Start Leading
summary: Industry bellwether UnitedHealth's second-quarter results show pandemic-driven disruptions are winding down. Healthcare stocks have been a laggard so far this year. That presents an opportunity for investors, because a strong second-quarter earnings season is in the cards.

title: U.S. Bids to Counter China on Global Infrastructure Aid
summary: Resume Subscription. ELEFSINA, Greece-An aging shipyard here has a new suitor sizing it up for investment: the U.S. government.

title: Levi's CFO Looks to Bring Down Debt Further as Business Recovers
summary: Bond repayment and refinancing bring down annual interest costs by about $20 million a year, says Harmit Singh. Levi Strauss & Co. is working to pay down the debt that the jeans maker took on during the onset of the pandemic, finance chief Harmit Singh said, joining other publicly traded companies that have reduced their financial obligations.

title: Morgan Stanley Profit Rises Amid Wall Street Deal Boom
summary: Boost in fees from deal making and advising wealthy clients helps bank's results. Morgan Stanley said Thursday that second-quarter profit rose 10% from a year earlier, thanks to a boost in fees from deal making and advising wealthy clients.

title: Indonesia's Hospitals Overflow With Covid-19 Patients
summary: A devastating coronavirus surge fueled by the Delta variant is tearing through the country and much of the largely unvaccinated developing world. JAKARTA, Indonesia-On a recent afternoon, 11 excavators were digging graves at a cemetery in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta. Ambulances lined up to unload coffins, as families grieved and prayed among the tombstones.

title: UnitedHealth's Profit Declines as Patients Seek Deferred Care
summary: Revenue rose amid growth in people served by the health insurer. People who delayed medical care during the peak of the U.S. coronavirus pandemic are heading back to their doctors, UnitedHealth Group Inc. said Thursday, with the trend cutting the company's profit in the latest quarter compared with a year ago.

title: U.S. Jobless Claims, Benefits Payments Fall to Pandemic Lows
summary: Applications for unemployment benefits declined to 360,000 last week, as recovery accelerates and states end extra pandemic-related aid early. Applications for unemployment benefits fell to a new pandemic low, showing a healing labor market, and the number of people receiving jobless aid has also trended lower as many states end enhanced pandemic programs.

title: The Pool's Oldest Lifeguard: 36-Year-Old Dives Into the Deep End for a Dream Job
summary: Resume Subscription. DORMONT, Pa.-Joshua Vish, at age 36, is the oldest lifeguard at the Dormont Pool. The job pays $15 an hour and is a dream come true, he said. Maybe even a life-saver.

title: Teachers Unions and Critical Race Theory in Schools
summary: Are they pushing 'honest history' or political indoctrination?. The editorial board, usually a champion of free speech, gets it plain wrong on the threat to teaching history posed by bans on critical race theory ("The Teachers Unions Go Woke," Review & Outlook, July 8). You claim these laws are harmless because "no one is opposed to teaching about America's difficult racial history, including the evils of slavery and Jim Crow."

title: Big Tech and the Global Minimum Corporate Tax Deal
summary: It protects the digital economy from unilateral foreign taxes.. In "It's Still a Bad Global Tax Deal" (July 9), the editorial board sharply criticizes a deal reached by 132 governments to overhaul global tax rules to address challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy. The editorial speaks of a "tech tax," alluding to the preliminary agreement on the reallocation of certain taxing rights. But there is no mention of a clear benefit and key driver of these negotiations: securing the removal of unilateral tax measures that attempt to ring-fence the digital economy and target U.S. companies.

title: Park It Outside, GM Tells Bolt Owners After Two Car Fires
summary: Last November, General Motors recalled nearly 69,000 Bolts from the 2017-19 model years, including roughly 51,000 sold in the U.S.. General Motors Co. is advising owners of its previously recalled Chevrolet Bolt electric vehicles to once again park outdoors after two cars that had been repaired caught fire.

title: Masks, Children and the Summer Heat
summary: My heart broke when I saw my 4-year old granddaughter's class picture.. Regarding Ashley E. McGuire's "It's 98 Degrees Out. Why Is My Child Wearing a Mask?" (op-ed, July 10): The other day my heart broke when I saw my 4-year-old granddaughter's class picture. Not a smile could be seen. She and all her little friends were wearing masks.

title: Why 1970s Inflation Numbers Are No More
summary: The consumer price index now measures housing costs differently.. Alan S. Blinder's op-ed "Don't Worry Too Much About the Inflation Surge" (July 8) omits an important part of the inflation story. Reported inflation can't go back to the double-digits of the 1970s and '80s because it is measured differently nowadays.

title: When Uncle Sam Needed a Favor, a Landlord in Washington Stepped Up
summary: Norman Bernstein, who has died at age 100, opened apartment buildings in the early 1960s to African diplomats and Black Americans. The U.S. State Department had an embarrassing problem in 1961: Newly independent African countries were sending diplomats to Washington, D.C., and landlords were refusing to rent apartments to those Black envoys.

title: The Airline Recovery Is Too Much Made in the USA
summary: While U.S. carriers are starting to make money again, international travel markets aren't yet enjoying the much-awaited recovery from the pandemic. The U.S. airline recovery may be too homemade for investors' taste.

title: Is a Graduate Degree Worth the Debt? Check It Here
summary: Thousands of university programs across the country are leaving students with big debts and skimpy incomes. Use this tool to see how your degree fares.. Lured by the aura of degrees from top-flight institutions, many master's degree students have taken on debt beyond what their pay after graduation would support. This finding was detailed recently in an article published by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Top EU Court Sets Limits on Workplace Head-Scarf Ban
summary: Ruling sets out conditions on when such prohibitions comply with the bloc's antidiscrimination laws. BRUSSELS-The European Union's top court said Thursday that employers may ban the wearing of head scarves and other religious symbols but set out conditions on when such prohibitions comply with the bloc's antidiscrimination laws.

title: Blackstone, AIG, NortonLifeLock, Morgan Stanley: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: AMC Entertainment fell in premarket trading, putting the favorite of Reddit traders on course to extend a recent slide. Futures are down ahead of a second day of testimony from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on Capitol Hill. New jobless claims fell to 360,000 last week from 386,000 the prior week. Here's what we're watching ahead of Thursday's trading action.

title: Boeing's CEO Is Trying to Overcome Problems. New Ones Keep Cropping Up.
summary: The aerospace giant's Dreamliner production slowdown is its latest setback as Boeing wrestles with problems large and small. Boeing Co. Chief Executive David Calhoun took over the top job in January 2020 with a mandate to overcome the company's management, engineering and production problems.

title: 'A Farewell to Gabo and Mercedes' Review: Love in the Time of Fame
summary: A son's memoir of the loss of his parents and the passing of an era in Colombian literature.. Mercedes Barcha liked to remind her two sons that "we are not public figures." Her husband used to insist that "everyone has three lives: the public, the private, and the secret." Their children grew up in a home where "the line between the public and the private" was strictly patrolled. Yet Rodrigo Garcia, the elder son of Mercedes and of Gabriel García Márquez, has now written a slim personal memoir about the final days of one of one of the planet's most renowned literary partnerships. Don't expect a tell-all confessional that breaks with every family principle of discretion. Garcia told his father's biographer that he imagined their tight-knit clan as "a wheel with four spokes." Charming and tender but elusive, "A Farewell to Gabo and Mercedes" (HarperVia, 157 pages, $23.99) proves that wheel remains something of a closed circle.

title: Shoring Up Beaches May Get Tougher Under Biden Administration
summary: White House could reverse Trump policy allowing use of federal funds to import beach sand from areas with protected wildlife habitat. Carolina Beach, N.C., faces a perennial problem-replacing the tons of sand regularly washed away so tourists visiting the barrier island have a spot to plunk down their blankets and umbrellas.

title: A British Open in Sandwich Means a Lot of Talk About the Weather
summary: Doused in rain or drenched in sun, the Royal St. George's Golf Club in southeast England transforms based on the mercurial weather. Shane Lowry arrived in the small town of Sandwich to defend his unusual two-year reign as the British Open champion, and the first words out of his mouth when he was asked to assess Royal St. George's Golf Club weren't at all about the course.

title: Cannes, Risking China's Ire, to Screen Hong Kong Protest Documentary
summary: Resume Subscription. The Cannes Film Festival plans to screen a controversial new documentary on Hong Kong's 2019 pro-democracy unrest on Friday, courting another film-industry clash with Beijing even as the sector remains heavily reliant on China for box-office success.

title: This Buzzy L.A. Restaurant Is Reinventing the Deli
summary: Yangban Society, from chefs Katianna and John Hong, aims to be a new kind of Korean-American deli, with a menu of inventive dishes.. Chefs Katianna and John Hong have been planning for this moment for years. "Over beers after work, John and I would always ask each other what kind of chefs we hoped to one day become," Katianna, 37, says, recalling the post-shift ritual she and her husband adopted while working at some of California's most celebrated restaurants. The couple is now answering that question with Yangban Society, a restaurant and market they are opening in September in Los Angeles's Arts District. "It's a big deli" is how John, 34, describes it at first.

title: How Prince Will Last Forever
summary: The artist's first complete posthumous release, 'Welcome 2 America,' arrives this summer. Also, an exhibition of his finest footwear. Behind the plans to make sure the Purple Rain never lets up.. Prince's 2016 death from an accidental fentanyl overdose at the age of 57 left a void for millions of adoring listeners worldwide. Yet as the singer once said: "Electric word, life / it means forever and that's a mighty long time / But I'm here to tell you there's something else / the afterworld."

title: Robinhood, Others Upend Rules for Early IPO Trading
summary: Traditional six-month lockup is eased for insiders wanting to sell stock after a company goes public. Robinhood Markets Inc. revolutionized online trading. Now, as it prepares to list its own shares, the upstart broker is taking aim at a pillar of the traditional IPO process: lockups.

title: TSMC Sees Chip Shortage Easing-but Geopolitics Aren't Going Away
summary: The world's largest contract chip maker has more demand for its products than it knows what to do with. Politics, not business, looks like the most pressing issue on the horizon.. Fresh off a quarter of record revenues, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. -the world's largest custom chip maker-expects the semiconductor shortage that has plagued car makers this year to ease. Strong demand for chips should nonetheless keep business humming. The company's biggest problem might be balancing the demands of so many interested parties: many of the world's largest companies and most powerful governments.

title: Get Vaxxed or Stay Home, Some Local Chinese Governments Say
summary: Some areas are planning to restrict people from public venues unless they get shots, sparking criticism. Several local governments in China are planning to bar residents who haven't been vaccinated against Covid-19 from accessing public venues, stirring controversy as the country makes a push for herd immunity.

title: TSMC Expects Auto-Chip Shortage to Abate This Quarter
summary: A dearth of semiconductors has stymied manufacturing activity in the auto industry. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. , the world's largest contract chip maker, said it expects the chip shortage that has hampered car makers to start easing in the next few months after it ramped up its production of auto chips.

title: Startups Cash In as Venture Funding for Digital Health Rises
summary: Entrepreneurs grab new funds to hire more staff, expand market share. Increasing venture-capital investment in digital health is helping startups accelerate their growth while also raising concerns that the market is overheating.

title: M.B.A. Programs From Stanford to Columbia and NYU Pass on Hybrid Learning
summary: Business schools want students back on campus; M.B.A. candidates say in-person networking makes the degree's cost worth it. Several high-profile M.B.A. programs have decided not to offer hybrid learning this fall.

title: EU, China Unveil Plans to Cut Emissions
summary: Moves reflect a new urgency to limit emissions in two of the world's biggest economies. The European Union and China presented sweeping plans to limit greenhouse-gas emissions that will increase costs for industry and consumers, though they drew criticism from environmentalists as not going far enough to slow climate change.

title: China to Walk a Fine Line After Growth in Second Quarter
summary: Beijing is on track to meet its full-year growth target of 6% or more, but mounting risks lurk beneath the solid numbers. HONG KONG-Despite a solid economic performance in the second quarter of the year, Chinese policy makers are expected to walk a fine line between supporting growth amid rising downside pressures and letting the economy run its course as they pivot to tackle longer-term challenges.

title: Your Child Tax Credit Payment Just Arrived. Are You Sure You Want It?
summary: More than 35 million U.S. households are now getting monthly cash payments of their 2021 child tax credits. While the payments will help some families greatly, they could also bring unexpected tax bills next year.. Check your bank account. It may have jumped today if you have children ages 17 or younger-thanks to the Internal Revenue Service, of all things.

title: Many Jobs Lost During the Pandemic Won't Be Coming Back
summary: Companies see automation and other labor-saving steps as a way to emerge from the health crisis with a permanently smaller workforce. Job openings are at a record high, leaving the impression that employers are hiring like never before. But many businesses that laid off workers during the pandemic are already predicting they will need fewer employees in the future.

title: Wall Street Opens Back Up to Oil and Gas-but Not for Drilling
summary: Oil-and-gas companies are using cash from debt offerings to shore up balance sheets rather than to boost production. Energy companies are raising money again from Wall Street at superlow borrowing costs, thanks in part to higher oil prices. The one thing most investors don't want them to do with it is pump more crude.

title: High-Speed Rail Gets Boost From New Coalition
summary: Business and labor groups want high-speed rail projects included in budget reconciliation. WASHINGTON-As Congress considers making the greatest single investment in passenger rail in U.S. history, a coalition of high-speed rail boosters is readying a response: Go faster, and spend more.

title: Tesla Battery Supplier Rides EV Boom to $200 Billion-Plus Valuation
summary: The Chinese company has been boosted by deals with Tesla and others, plus record sales growth at local EV makers. China's battery champion is drawing strength from the electric-vehicle boom.

title: U.S. Competition Policy Is Aligning With Europe, and Deeper Cooperation Could Follow
summary: Biden's appointments, actions auger 'much more intense work' between Washington and Brussels, says EU competition chief Vestager. The European Union's top antitrust regulator foresees greater alignment with the U.S. on competition enforcement, particularly in the tech sector, amid a broader policy reorientation under the Biden administration.

title: What's Worse Than a Chip Shortage? Buying Fake Ones
summary: Global semiconductor shortage attracts fraudsters, counterfeits; 'Of course, a bunch of them didn't work,' a buyer says. TAIPEI-The global chip shortage has created a gold mine for bad actors.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Thwaaap! Giannis Blocks a Shot-and Milwaukee and Phoenix Have a Series
summary: A brilliant defensive play by the two-time MVP prevents a dunk, and NBA Finals are thrillingly deadlocked. The NBA Finals between Milwaukee and Phoenix are knotted 2-2 after Milwaukee's impressive 109-103 come-from-behind win Wednesday. A few quick thoughts:

title: Delta Reports First Profit Since Covid-19 Pandemic, Helped by U.S. Aid
summary: Demand has been 'overwhelming' as vacationers rush back, although corporate and international travel remain weak. Delta Air Lines Inc. said U.S. vacation travel has fully recovered as the airline reported its first quarterly profit since the Covid-19 pandemic crushed the industry last year.

title: China's Economic Growth Slows in the Second Quarter
summary: Economists widely expected growth to trend lower beginning in the second quarter. BEIJING-China's economic rebound slowed in the second quarter but continued to show unusual resilience more than a year after the country largely got control of the coronavirus within its borders.

title: Powell Says Fed Still Expects Inflation to Ease
summary: Federal Reserve is still 'a ways off' from reducing asset purchases, central bank chairman tells Congress. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank wouldn't hesitate to raise interest rates to keep inflation under control but repeatedly emphasized he still expects price pressures to ease later this year.

title: J&J Recalls Aveeno, Neutrogena Spray Sunscreens
summary: Company is pulling the products after detecting a cancer-causing chemical known as benzene in some samples. Johnson & Johnson is recalling most of its Neutrogena and Aveeno spray sunscreens from U.S. stores after detecting benzene, a potentially cancer-causing chemical, in some samples.

title: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro Admitted to São Paulo Hospital for Intestinal Obstruction
summary: He underwent testing but hasn't needed surgery. SÃO PAULO-Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro was transported by air late Wednesday afternoon for medical treatment in São Paulo after his doctor diagnosed him with an intestinal obstruction earlier in the day in the capital, Brasília.

title: Britney Spears Retains New Lawyer at Emotional Hearing
summary: Greenberg Traurig's Mathew Rosengart told judge he will petition to remove her father, James Spears. LOS ANGELES-Britney Spears retained a new lawyer, Greenberg Traurig LLP's Mathew Rosengart, Wednesday who promised to petition the court to remove Ms. Spears's father, James Spears, from his role as her conservator.
